dt.t: {wi}sojourned{/wi} for a month at a resort

quotes.t: … there abode, in a remote period of American history, that is to say, some thirty years since, a worthy wight of the name of Ichabod Crane, who {qword}sojourned{/qword}, or, as he expressed it, "tarried," in Sleepy Hollow, for the purpose of instructing the children of the vicinity.
'Am I hideous, Jane?' 'Very, sir: you always were, you know.' 'Humph! The wickedness has not been taken out of you, wherever you have {qword}sojourned{/qword}.'

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}sujurner, sejurner{/it}, from Vulgar Latin {it}*subdiurnare{/it}, from Latin {it}sub{/it} under, during + Late Latin {it}diurnum{/it} day {ma}{mat|up|}, {mat|journey|}{/ma}
shortdef: to stay as a temporary resident : stop
